awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Software-Defined Networking and Resource Virtualization in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) Satellite Constellations
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is the extension of state-of-the-art terrestrial 5G technologies to non-terrestrial satellite networks. Non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) are the ideal hosts for many commercial applications involving monitoring, reconnaissance, and remote sensing such as agricultural planting, remote factory operations, and industrial automation. These applications will demand significant computation and bandwidth resources from NTNs. Virtualization technologies like software-defined networking (SDN) and network slicing are key enablers for similar applications in terrestrial networks, but satellite networks pose a unique set of challenges to existing 5G technologies. NTNs have complex and highly dynamic topologies caused by both the predictable movement of satellites as well as unpredictable weather events interfering with satellite-to-ground links. Extending 5G algorithms to NTNs enables new applications and unlocks additional network capacity without launching any new satellites. 5G virtualization also simplifies access to satellite constellations. Customers can interact with multiple satellite networks via the same virtual network interface, eliminating the need to learn different interfaces for different constellations. This Phase I project will explore more efficient networking solutions that satellite network operators can use to supply the growing demand for satellite internet. 

This SBIR Phase I project explores methods of extending SDN and virtual network slicing technologies into space given the challenges posed by NTN topologies. First, it proposes a "NextG" framework for non-terrestrial SDN using existing 5G technologies whose core orchestrator can create end-to-end slices for seamless communication over terrestrial and NTN. In SDN, one or multiple software entities called controllers are responsible for the control of the network. The number and locations of controllers in the network and how often these controllers communicate can be selected to balance latency in the NTN and the overhead costs from sending synchronization messages. This project explores the use of deep reinforcement learning algorithms to learn optimal controller placement and synchronization strategies. Second, network slices are independent virtual networks that share a common infrastructure of network resources. Offline algorithms are used to allocate network resources to slices based on the requests of the virtual network operator. Subsequently, online algorithms dynamically reprovision network resources in real-time depending on the slices' actual resource usages. The team will investigate integer programming techniques for virtual network embedding that scale to larger NTN topologies and deep reinforcement learning agents for online resource scaling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Under its NSF funded SBIR Phase I project "Software-Defined Resource Orchestration for Non-Terrestrial Networks and Satellite Edge Computing", Uninet organized its research and development into three major products/accomplishments: (i) a non-terrestrial network (NTN) platform for seamless simulation and emulation with real and synthetic satellites, (ii) an optimization approach to NTN topology design and control, and (iii) a job scheduler for resource allocation in the satellite edge cloud (SEC).

Background: Non-terrestrial computational and communications resources provided by constellations of low-Earth orbiting (LEO) satellites are revolutionizing 5G/6G networking infrastructure and beyond. Large constellations like SpaceX’s Starlink provide universal connectivity to the Internet in the most remote locations on Earth. Smaller Earth-observation constellations monitor, track, and forecast wildfires in real time using cameras and other sensors in space. Whereas the transformative potential of these LEO satellite applications is virtually unlimited, the supply of space-based resources required to support them is not. Compared to the routers, base stations, and computational nodes that comprise terrestrial 5G network and cloud infrastructures, satellites in NTNs are significantly more expensive, hardware resource-limited, and complex. To accommodate the growing complexity of NTN applications, Uninet investigated various software-only resource allocation techniques to increase the capacity of NTNs by leveraging current non-terrestrial resources more efficiently rather than by launching new satellites.

Software-Defined Networking (SDN) Platform: The space industry has tremendous barriers of entry to businesses both small and large. By leveraging SDN paradigms like virtualization, our platform enables satellite companies to rapidly prototype new algorithms terrestrially and avoid the risks and expenses of operating in space. Uninet’s SDN platform can simultaneously incorporate real-time telemetry and network data for orbiting satellites alongside synthetic satellites. Uninet’s platform enables us and our customers to design and prototype new NTN algorithms rapidly, monitor and control the health and status of networks, and visualize NTN/SDN/constellation information in human-readable formats. The platform seamlessly integrates simulated and real-word satellites, allowing constellation operators to fine-tune their SDN algorithms on a variety of NTN configurations without launching any additional satellites and guarantee functionality of these algorithms past the prototype stage and into production.

Optimal Network Design and Control for Mega-Constellations: Satellites communicate in space via optical laser connections. If satellites in NTNs were waypoints in a road-network, the links between them would correspond to the roads that connect waypoints; network packets would be the cars; and network control policies would give drivers the directions to get from A to B. Uninet developed two novel optimization approaches to building roads between waypoints to minimize latency (travel-time) and maximize throughput (the number of cars the road network can support without congestion). Our optimized network design reduces latency by up to 80% compared to Starlink. Additionally, we developed a NTN-compatible routing algorithm to minimize congestion. Our "Backpressure" routing algorithm increases network throughput by 37% compared to a baseline open shortest path first (OSPF) routing in emulation.

Satellite Edge Cloud (SEC) Resource Allocation: The paradigm of "network slicing" transforms traditional networking by dividing a shared physical infrastructure into independent, virtualized logical networks called "slices." Each slice is tailored to specific applications and dynamically scales resources to meet varying demands. In NTNs, this technology is particularly transformative, enabling operators to form distributed, cloud-based networks in space that complement terrestrial cloud infrastructure. For example, satellites monitoring agricultural fields can use slices optimized for processing hyperspectral data, while others tasked with tracking orbital debris may prioritize low-latency decision-making for collision avoidance. By processing user applications directly on satellites, network slicing enables a proliferated satellite edge cloud (SEC) where time-sensitive and resource intensive applications can avoid the long delays and significant bandwidth costs associated with transmitting data generated in space back to Earth for analysis. Uninet has designed an optimization platform called "SchedUP" based on integer linear programming (ILP) to allocate network slices within the SEC. SchedUP generates scheduling decisions based on applications’ resource profiles, satellite telemetries, and energy resource generation/depletion rates. SchedUP coordinates resources across multiple network slices and reduces the run-time of Earth-Observation applications by 15% compared to the state-of-the-art.

Overall, our research highlights the feasibility and value of softwarizing NTNs. By leveraging software-defined networking and satellite edge cloud paradigms, Uninet delivers flexible solutions to improve NTN user experiences. Uninet envisions a future where NTNs are fully softwarized, providing end-users with the ability to control and customize their Earth-observation and other missions with unprecedented flexibility. By leveraging innovations in SDN, network slicing, and edge cloud scheduling, Uninet aims to adapt state-of-the-art methods from today’s terrestrial networks to meet the challenges of space-based systems. Our long-term goal is to establish a seamless bridge between terrestrial and NTNs. This vision will revolutionize how end-users manage space-based resources.
